definition: A highly aggressive primary cutaneous neuroendocrine carcinoma.
clinical: Rapidly enlarging erythematous nodule. Occurs in older patients, typically with fair skin on sun-exposed sites (head and neck). Immunosuppression is a significant risk factor.
pathogenesis: Two distinct etiologic pathways: 1) Merkel Cell Polyomavirus (MCPyV) positive (70-80% of North American cases, integrated into genome, truncated Large T-antigen, better prognosis). 2) Virus-negative (UV-driven, high mutational burden including p53, RB, and Notch pathways, worse prognosis).
macroscopic: Erythematous nodule; clinical size is the most important metric for staging.
microscopic: Diffusely infiltrative small round blue cell tumor. Patterns include sheets, nests, trabeculae, or clusters. Cells have large nuclei with little cytoplasm (high N:C ratio), finely granular ('salt and pepper') chromatin, and nuclear molding. High mitotic rate and numerous apoptotic bodies. Often prone to crush artifact.
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: CK20 (characteristic large paranuclear dots), Neurofilament (paranuclear dots), INSM1 (highly sensitive nuclear marker), Synaptophysin, Chromogranin, CD56, MCPyV T-antigen (CM2B4 antibody). IHC Negatives: TTF-1 (excludes lung small cell), CK7, LCA/CD45 (excludes lymphoma), S100/Melan-A (excludes melanoma).
differential_diagnosis: Metastatic Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (TTF-1+, CK7+, CK20-), Basal Cell Carcinoma, Melanoma, Lymphoma, Ewing Sarcoma.
staging: Staged by clinical size of primary tumor. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is important for staging nodal disease. Prognosis depends on viral status (virus-positive is better) and immune status (immunosuppression is worse).
prognosis_and_prediction: Aggressive. Virus-positive tumors have better progression-free and overall survival independent of stage. Tumors with robust CD8+ T-cell infiltrates have better outcomes.

related_figures.legend: Low power view showing a diffusely infiltrative small round blue cell tumor replacing the dermis. (Time: 77s)
High power showing high N:C ratio, finely granular chromatin, nuclear molding, and mitoses. (Time: 148s)
CK20 immunohistochemistry showing characteristic large paranuclear dot-like positivity. (Time: 278s)
INSM1 positivity, a highly sensitive nuclear marker for neuroendocrine differentiation. (Time: 526s)

definition: An intraepithelial adenocarcinoma involving apocrine-rich skin (anogenital, axillary).
clinical: Erythematous, eczematoid, slowly spreading plaque. Anogenital and axillary areas.
pathogenesis: May be primary (cutaneous adnexal origin) or secondary (extension from internal malignancy, e.g., colorectal or urothelial).
microscopic: Intraepidermal proliferation of malignant epithelioid cells with pale or basophilic cytoplasm ('buckshot' scatter). Distinctive feature: Paget cells often spare the basal layer of keratinocytes (unlike melanoma or SCC). Underlying dermis often shows smooth muscle (anogenital/areolar skin).
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: CK7, CAM5.2, CEA, Mucin stains (Mucicarmine). IHC Negatives: p63, CK5/6, SOX10, S100, Melan-A. (Note: CK20/CDX2 may be positive in secondary disease from GI).
differential_diagnosis: Squamous Cell Carcinoma in situ (p63+, CK5/6+), Melanoma in situ (S100+, SOX10+), Sebaceous Carcinoma.
staging: Assessment for underlying internal malignancy is crucial.
prognosis_and_prediction: Slowly progressive but can be invasive.

related_figures.legend: Intraepidermal proliferation of large epithelioid cells. (Time: 1384s)
Mucicarmine stain highlighting intracytoplasmic mucin (red). (Time: 1452s)
CAM5.2 positive in tumor cells; p63 highlights background keratinocytes but is negative in tumor. (Time: 1470s)

definition: A malignant adnexal carcinoma related to hidradenoma, often aggressive.
clinical: Face and extremities. Aggressive course with potential for lymph node, lung, and bone metastases.
pathogenesis: Can arise de novo or from a pre-existing hidradenoma. Enriched for p53 mutations.
microscopic: Infiltrative growth pattern. High-grade cytology: large pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear membranes, clumpy chromatin, prominent nucleoli. High mitotic rate and necrosis. May show remnants of benign hidradenoma (clear cells, eosinophilic cells, hyalinized stroma).
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: CK7, CEA, p53 (diffuse/mutated pattern). Genetics: Gene rearrangements (MAML2 implied in benign precursor); p53 mutations.
differential_diagnosis: Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma (PAX8+), Sebaceous Carcinoma (vacuoles indenting nucleus), Apocrine Carcinoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Poor prognosis due to metastatic potential.

related_figures.legend: Low power showing transition from benign hidradenoma to high-grade carcinoma. (Time: 1668s)
Malignant cytology: pleomorphism, necrosis, and irregular chromatin. (Time: 1779s)

definition: A malignant sweat gland tumor occurring on the digits (formerly Aggressive Digital Papillary Adenocarcinoma).
clinical: Solitary painless mass on fingers, toes, palms, or soles. Can occur in both young and older patients. Aggressive with high metastatic rate.
microscopic: Solid and cystic growth with distinct papillary formations (fibrovascular cores lined by multiple layers of epithelial cells). Cells may be basaloid. Poorly circumscribed.
staging: High risk of metastasis (lung, lymph nodes).
prognosis_and_prediction: Requires wide local excision or amputation due to aggressive behavior.

related_figures.legend: Solid and cystic growth with papillary formations on acral skin. (Time: 1964s)
Papillae with fibrovascular cores lined by multiple layers of epithelial cells. (Time: 1978s)

definition: A low-grade cutaneous neuroendocrine/mucinous carcinoma, considered a precursor to primary cutaneous mucinous carcinoma.
clinical: Elderly females. Predilection for eyelid, cheek, and face.
microscopic: Multi-lobulated tumor in dermis. Solid and cystic areas with 'pseudo-papillary' structures (no true fibrovascular cores). Cells are relatively banal with neuroendocrine (finely granular) chromatin. Intracellular and extracellular mucin. Can transition into Mucinous Carcinoma (nests floating in large pools of mucin).
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: CK7, Estrogen Receptor (ER), Progesterone Receptor (PR), INSM1, Synaptophysin, Chromogranin. Markers like WT1 (often positive, not explicitly mentioned but standard).
differential_diagnosis: Mucinous Carcinoma (more extensive mucin pools), Metastatic Breast Carcinoma.

related_figures.legend: Lobulated tumor with pseudo-papillary structures and mucin. (Time: 2219s)
Transition to mucinous carcinoma with epithelial nests floating in extracellular mucin. (Time: 2311s)

definition: A locally aggressive, infiltrating, sclerosing adnexal carcinoma.
clinical: Commonly upper lip and nasolabial fold. 5th-6th decade.
microscopic: Superficial keratinous cysts (resembling trichoadenoma/desmoplastic trichoepithelioma) blending into small ductal structures and cords in the deep dermis. Diffusely infiltrative into subcutis/muscle with a dense desmoplastic stroma. Cytologically bland cells. Perineural invasion is very common.
differential_diagnosis: Syringoma, Desmoplastic Trichoepithelioma, Squamous Cell Carcinoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: High recurrence rate if not completely excised; low metastatic potential.

related_figures.legend: Superficial keratocysts overlying infiltrative small ducts. (Time: 2465s)
Diffusely infiltrative cords and small ducts in desmoplastic stroma. (Time: 2485s)

definition: A rare primary cutaneous carcinoma identical to salivary gland adenoid cystic carcinoma.
clinical: Slow growing tumor in older patients.
microscopic: Basaloid cells arranged in cribriform ('Swiss cheese'), tubular, or solid patterns. Mucin often present in pseudocysts. Perineural invasion is ubiquitous.
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: MYB (nuclear), CD117 (c-kit), p63, SOX10. Genetics: MYB fusions.
differential_diagnosis: Basal Cell Carcinoma, Adenoid Basal Cell Carcinoma.

related_figures.legend: Classic cribriform architecture with basaloid cells and mucin-filled spaces. (Time: 2523s)
Perineural invasion by tumor nests. (Time: 2565s)

definition: A malignant adnexal tumor with eccrine differentiation, arising de novo or from a poroma.
clinical: Older patients, acral skin (palms/soles) or lower extremities.
microscopic: Infiltrative growth with connection to the epidermis (intraepidermal nesting/pagetoid spread). Poroid cells (basaloid) forming ducts/lumina. High grade features: necrosis, high mitotic rate, nuclear pleomorphism.

related_figures.legend: Infiltrative tumor with epidermal connection and high-grade cytology. (Time: 2690s)
Ductal differentiation within solid nests of atypical cells. (Time: 2711s)

definition: A malignant mesenchymal neoplasm of the dermis, diagnosis of exclusion.
clinical: Rapidly growing, ulcerated nodule on sun-damaged skin (head/neck) of elderly patients.
microscopic: Restricted to the dermis (if involves subcutis/necrosis/vascular invasion, termed Pleomorphic Dermal Sarcoma). Pleomorphic spindle and epithelioid cells, bizarre giant cells, atypical mitoses. High grade morphology.
ancillary_studies: IHC: Diagnosis of exclusion. Positives: CD10 (diffuse), p53 (diffuse/mutated), Procollagen-1. Negatives (CRITICAL): Cytokeratins/p40/p63 (excludes SCC), S100/SOX10/Melan-A (excludes Melanoma), Desmin (excludes Leiomyosarcoma), Erg (excludes Angiosarcoma).
differential_diagnosis: Pleomorphic Dermal Sarcoma (same tumor, deeper/more aggressive), Spindle Cell SCC, Desmoplastic Melanoma, Leiomyosarcoma, Angiosarcoma.
staging: AFX has low metastatic potential; Pleomorphic Dermal Sarcoma has higher metastatic risk.

related_figures.legend: Highly pleomorphic spindle and epithelioid cells with bizarre nuclei. (Time: 2829s)
Atypical mitotic figures and marked nuclear pleomorphism. (Time: 2850s)

definition: Cutaneous metastasis from primary breast malignancy.
clinical: Nodules typically near the site of the primary (chest wall, abdomen). Commonest cutaneous met in women.
microscopic: Tumor in dermis with no connection to epidermis. Ductal type: gland/tubule formation. Lobular type: single file 'Indian-filing' of cells between collagen bundles.
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: CK7, Mammaglobin, GATA3, ER/PR/Her2 (depending on primary). E-cadherin positive in Ductal, Negative in Lobular. IHC Negatives: p63, CK20.

related_figures.legend: Glandular structures in dermis without epidermal connection. (Time: 3184s)
Single file infiltration of tumor cells between collagen bundles. (Time: 3270s)

definition: Cutaneous metastasis from primary lung malignancy.
clinical: Rapidly growing nodules, scalp is a common site. Common in men.
microscopic: Adenocarcinoma: Glandular formation. Small Cell Carcinoma: Small round blue cells (mimics Merkel).
ancillary_studies: Adenocarcinoma: TTF-1+, Napsin A+, CK7+. Small Cell: TTF-1+, CK7+, INSM1+, CK20- (usually), MCPyV-.
differential_diagnosis: Merkel Cell Carcinoma (CK20+, TTF-1-), Primary Adnexal Carcinoma.

related_figures.legend: Glandular tumor in dermis, TTF-1 positive. (Time: 3306s)
Small round blue cell tumor, TTF-1 positive, CK20 negative. (Time: 3369s)

definition: Cutaneous metastasis from primary colorectal malignancy.
microscopic: Glandular structures with characteristic 'dirty necrosis' (central necrotic debris). No epidermal connection.
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: CK20, CDX2. IHC Negatives: CK7.

related_figures.legend: Glands with central 'dirty' necrosis. (Time: 3407s)

definition: Cutaneous metastasis from renal cell carcinoma.
clinical: Vascular nodules, often head and neck.
microscopic: Clear cells arranged in nests or sheets. Highly vascular stroma with hemorrhage/red blood cells. Lack of epidermal connection.
ancillary_studies: IHC Positives: PAX8, RCC antigen, Vimentin. IHC Negatives: CK7, CK20, p63.
differential_diagnosis: Clear Cell Hidradenoma (CK7+, p63+), Sebaceous Carcinoma.

related_figures.legend: Clear cells with prominent vascularity and hemorrhage; PAX8 positive. (Time: 3467s)
